channel.title: Comments on: Dinosaur cells identified with possible dino-DNA!

item.title: By: The Week in Science (Feb 11-17) | Science Communication Blog Network
item.dc:creator: The Week in Science (Feb 11-17) | Science Communication Blog Network
item.description: [...] Dinosaur cells identified with possible dino-DNA! [...]
item.content:encoded: […] Dinosaur cells identified with possible dino-DNA! […]

item.title: By: kindredspirit23
item.dc:creator: kindredspirit23
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/dinosaur-cells-identified-with-possible-dino-dna/#comment-376">protohedgehog</a>.
I will stick with the "they might get a chicken" thing. What's going to happen is they will end up creating something that reproduces quickly, grows to about 5 feet tall, is deadly, and doesn't like us. Too many Sci-fy movies, I think.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to protohedgehog.

I will stick with the “they might get a chicken” thing. What’s going to happen is they will end up creating something that reproduces quickly, grows to about 5 feet tall, is deadly, and doesn’t like us.
Too many Sci-fy movies, I think.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/dinosaur-cells-identified-with-possible-dino-dna/#comment-375">kindredspirit23</a>.
Ha!
I think the idea is that you can reverse engineer a genome in early developmental stages to sort of craft the phenotype through ontogeny, by applying the right tweaks and the right chemicals at the right time. I think Jack Horner has a book on it!
item.content:encoded:
In reply to kindredspirit23.

Ha!

I think the idea is that you can reverse engineer a genome in early developmental stages to sort of craft the phenotype through ontogeny, by applying the right tweaks and the right chemicals at the right time. I think Jack Horner has a book on it!

item.title: By: kindredspirit23
item.dc:creator: kindredspirit23
item.description: So, if I understand you, scientists in Japan may be able to use these bits of leftover DNA in chickens and, perhaps, make...a chicken?! You would really think that any society with Godzilla in their past would shy away from dinosaur DNA testing.
item.content:encoded:
So, if I understand you, scientists in Japan may be able to use these bits of leftover DNA in chickens and, perhaps, make…a chicken?!
You would really think that any society with Godzilla in their past would shy away from dinosaur DNA testing.
